context: [5] Changes in perfusion pressure were measured with a pressure transducer approximately 15 cm from the tip of the cannula.  [6] The preparation was allowed to equilibrate for 30 to 45 min, and its viability was checked by a bolus injection of 6 Ã— 10âˆ’5 mol of KCl.  [7] Then the preparation was perfused with noradrenaline (3 Ã— 10âˆ’6M), which induced a sustained increase in perfusion pressure, and a concentration-response curve was constructed by perfusing with increasing concentrations (10âˆ’7â€“3 Ã— 10âˆ’5 M) of the flavonoids.  [8] In some experiments, the guanylate cyclase inhibitor 1H-[1,2,4]oxadiazolo[4,3-a]quinoxalin-1-one (ODQ; 10âˆ’6 M), the adenylate cyclase inhibitor SQ22536 [9-(tetrahydro-2-furanyl)-9H-purin-6-amine; 10âˆ’6 M], KCl (40 mM, with isotonic replacement by NaCl), or the Na+/K+ATPase inhibitor ouabain (10âˆ’3 M) was present in the noradrenaline-solution. [10] The functional endothelium removal procedure was verified by the lack of relaxant effect of a bolus of acetylcholine (10 nmol). Quinoxaline, specifically the compound 1H-[1,2,4]oxadiazolo[4,3-a]quinoxalin-1-one (ODQ), is used as a guanylate cyclase inhibitor, which may influence the signaling pathways involving AMP. However, the context does not provide a direct interaction or detailed relationship between AMP and quinoxaline beyond their involvement in the same experimental setup.
